Entry.1:
Enlisted at
Victoria Barracks, Sydney
, together with my comrade, Doug Black. Afterwards in camp at Warwick-Farm and
Liverpool
where at different times I played the parts of Coy. Sgt. Major, Sergt. and Private.
Entry.4: Battn. on H.M.A.S. Euripides (15000 tons), as acting Sergeant, bound for the war, destination unknown, but with great hopes and expectations.
Entry.5:
Called at
Port Melbourne
, to drop sick and take on mails.

Called at
Albury (W.A.)
after crossing the "
Bight",
my first experience of rough weather - Crossing the
Indian Ocean
we had beautiful weather, passed few ships, and saw no land at all, we were out of

the usual steamship routes. - Tropical storms of short duration often passed over us, these could be seen approaching, and after drenching us with rain for a few minutes, would leave again a seaof calm, and a sky of cloudless blue.

Indeed a pleasant trip during which I learned many things, and made many friends.
Entry.6:
Disembarked at
Suez
, after lying at the Canal-mouth (on which played a search-light) all night. - Suez, a lazy, hot, sleepy, town, a combination of sand, niggers, and flies. - By train (via
Ismalia
) to
Cairo
, passed desert lands broken here & there by "oasis-villages" and pestered by Arabs selling oranges. Detrained at
Zeitoun
and encamped on the desert at
Abbassia
(famous for its barracks) - Training hard here - on Christmas day "Billy-cans" and "Comforts" were distributed.

1916
Entry.7:
New-Year saw us at
Kasr-el-Nil
Barracks, and on picquet duty in the city to quell possible riots which however were not as serious as was anticipated.
Entry.10:
Birthday, duely celebrated at Abbassia - We shifted camp to 
Heliopolis
 (connected to Cairo by the best tram service I have ever seen) - More hard training in the boiling sun here.

Anuncanny experience on a picquet at 
Mancheit-el-Sadir
.

A picquet for two weeks at 
Bab-el-Sharia 
(
WassaDistrict
) during which I had many experiences, and learned a lot about the natives - These picquets were night affairs and we spent the day at Kasr-el-Nil.

During all this time I learned Cairo fairly thoroughly - visited its Mosques, Bazaars, Museums etc, and got toknow the wily native - visited the 
Pyramids and Sphinx at Giza 
several times, also the 
Citadel
.

Cairo has a fascination and smell all its own.
Entry.12:
Entrained for 
Tel-el-Kebir 
(here was fought the battle of Tel-el-Kebir in 1882 when "Fuzzy Wuzzy" broke the British Square, but was defeated by Wolsely). Joined the
Entry.13:
Infantry Battalion

Just back from Gallipoli, and reverted to Private.
Entry.14: Against my will I was separated from my comrade Doug.and sent to "C" Coy and given one stripe.
Entry.15:
The Bn. moved to 
Serapeum
 for garrison work and encamped a few miles on the 
Asiatic side 
of the 
Suez-Canal
, my recollections of this "Hell-on-earth" are anything but pleasant for apart from training that would break the heart of a lion, I think ofthirst, sandstorms, full marching-order, outposts at night and flies and sand.

The only pleasant break was a swim in the canal sometimes and that was salt,and we had to walk 3 miles through soft sand to get there, and another 3 back. Here we were visited by the Prince of Wales, but he didn't stay long.
Entry.16:
Right glad we were to pack up to entrain for 
Alexandria
, enroute for 
France
. - We boarded HMT "Simla" (a rotten ship), called at 
Malta
 on
Entry.17:
(what a change to be at sea again, in spite of "life-belts all the way" and "submarine guards" - Arrived at 
Marseilles
 on
Entry.19:
The beginning of a wonderful train journey, which lasted 3 days and 3 nights and took us right across France - The charm of the 
South of France 
in its very green gown of early spring, to our eyes, long tired with sand and desert, held us spell-bound, and as we passed on and on, past rivers, mountains and great manufacturing towns, Lyons, Avignon, Verseilles and Paris itself, cheered by the people, we were thinking "Here surely is a land worth fighting for."
Entry.20:
Our destination at last, 
Hazebrouck
 a town in 
Northern Flanders
, and as we passed along its cobbled roads, (oftimes since cursed right heartily) we heard the first far away rumble of the guns in the battle zone - some 20 miles distant. We marched to a small village,

Staple 
- Stayed here 8 days - ourfirst taste of billets - I was in afarm-house - We always rememberStaple - its good people and itscheap eggs and beer (1d per glass).
Entry.21:
Moved to 
Outtersteen
e, nearer theguns, visited 
Bailleul, Merris, Meteran, St Omer 
and 
Cassel
 during our stay here. - Here also I was made a temporary corporal.
Entry.22:
Moved to 
Sailly-sur-le-Lys
, which showed signs of shrapnel and shells but civilians still lived here.
Entry.23:
Moved to reserves at 
Croix-Blanc 
corner outside 
Fleurbaix
.
Here I first saw a shell burst, under amusing , if excitingcircumstances, for it burst in our house.
Next we moved to 
Fleurbaix
 village and I had my first taste of fatigues, up as far as the support line.
Entry.24:
We took over the 
front line Trenches
 relieving a Manchester (bantam) Regt.



and here in this "quiet sector" 
(Fromelles
) I found it very lively at times; I learned the secrets of "stand-to", "patrols" "trench-mortars", "sand-bags", "shovels", "rum", "bullets", "anti-gas appliances", "shells" and the many other things connected with "
trench-warfare
" - here also I saw men wounded and killed for the first time, and this is where the glamour and excitement started to wear off.
Entry.25: Found us back in "Sailly" for a "rest" which consisted of drill during the day and carrying stuff to the trenches at night. All our rests were like that.
Entry.26:
I attended a two days gas-school at
Nouveau-Monde
and sneaked vists to 
Estaires
 and 
Armentieres
.
Entry.27:
"
Jay Post
" A detached post in the support line; where I was in charge of No10 Platoon (30-40 men) and had no officer; consequently learned what responsibility was - here also I was promoted to full corporal.
Entry.28:
In what was the 
convent of Fleurbaix
 and did fatigues to such places as "Tin Barn Avenue" "Wye Farm" "Dead Dog Avenue" etc.
Entry.29:
In the line again, just on the left of where we were before "
Bois Grenier
". Here our sergeant also came back for which we were very thankful. I didn't like his job a bit.
Entry.30:
Back again in "
Sailly
" less just one or two of the old boys - This was a time of trouble for us all "Joe", poor old "Joe" lost his stripe and then "Jordo" was on the mat for stouching a "Military Policeman" and even I did notescape, forcheeking our Sergt Major I was severly reprimanded.
Entry.31:
On the train at 
Bailleul
, and rumour says we are on our way to the 
Somme
, to take part in the great battle there which started on
Entry.33:
Detrained at 
Heinville-Candas
 (
via Doullens
) and marched to 
St Ouen
 (14 Kilometres).
Entry.35:
Marched to 
Allonville
 (16 kilometres).
The above three days march though hard, were through beautiful country - the wheat fields were ablaze with golden wheat, red poppies and blue

cornflowers - truly a beautiful sight (but how we cursed those cobbled roads).
Entry.36:
Here I managed to get poisoned and was sent to the C.C.S. at 
Allonville
.
Entry.37:
Being pretty bad still, was put on a hospital train and found myself in an Australian Hospital at 
Rouen
. The doctors and nurses were kindness itself.
Entry.38:
Hospital ship "Aberdonian" via
 Havre
 to 
Southampton
 (held up a day at Havre on account of Submarines). I was a stretcher case and did not see much of the journey.
Train from 
Southampton 
to 
Birmingham 
my first glimpse of "
old England
" - in hospital at 
Kings Heath
 (board-school) and had a very nice time.
Entry.39:
To Aust Convalescent Hosp. 
Harefield Park
 (
Bucks
) while here had several outings including one round 
Windsor 
and 
Gerrard's Cross
.
Entry.40:
Sent to camp at 
Weymouth (Monte Video
) A good time here and visited

Portland
 and 
Bournmouth 
(Dorset).
Entry.41:
Start of furlough. 
LONDON
 - my first visit. I thoroughly explored its many famous places.The Tower,St Pauls, Westminster Abbey, etc. etc. Was also introduced to Horseferry Rd, well known to all Australian Soldiers.
Entry.42:
Left London (Euston Station) for 
Scotland
. Arrived at Stirling next day. Travelled via 
Crewe
, 
Carlisle
 and 
Glasgow.
A few hours in Stirling gave me a look at its famous castle and also the "William Wallace Memorial"and had a glimpse of 
Bannockburn 
and 
Bridge-of-Alan
 - travelled on same day to 
Ballachulish 
(via 
Connel-Ferry
). Through beautiful Scottish scenery; Lochs and Braes. The heather was out and the country-side truely at its best.
Entry.43:
A fine trip up 
Loch Leven
, by ferry passed the 
Valley of Glencoe
 and on to 
Kinlochleven 
- Here in this tiny village I stayed with friends and had a really fine holiday.

- Had a trip round to 
Oban,
 a pretty West Coast fishing village. - Then spent a week-end at 
Glasgow
, staying with newly-made friends at
 Bellahouston
.
Everywhere in Scotland I was overwhelmed with kindness - I never met such hospitable people.
Entry.44:
Found me again in 
London
, and the next day 
Weymouth
 again - what that first furlough meant to me only those who have had a like experience can know.
Entry.45:
Found me at 
Perham Downs
; the most dreary part of dreary 
Salisbury Plains
. I had an opportunity here of visiting 
Andover
 and 
Tidworth
 two more or less military towns close by.
Here also I learned much to my sorrow, of the death in Action of my mate Doug. Black. and alas many another good comrade in the terrible slaughter at Pozieres and Mouquet Farm, which

I, luckily for myself, just missed.
Entry.46:
Found me on my way to 
France
and the Battalion again. I went from 
Folkestone 
to 
Boulogne
 and then by train to our base at 
Etaples,
 where I stayed, over a week, passing doctors, and drilling atthe famous bull-ring.
Entry.47:
After two days train journey we arrived at 
Albert
(much talked of then) and here we stayed for a few days, and became familiar with "
Somme
" mud. We tramped through miles of this sticky, slimy repulsive mud (sometimes up to our knees) up to 
Delville-Wood
,which place of ill fame had been captured a few weeks before, after changing hands several times (it was here that the South Africans did so well but alas were almost wiped out.- Scottish troops also had been in the thick of it,for the remains of the fight lay thick

about us - Broken guns - dead horses and dead men, both British & German and these sights sort of slightly put the wind up one of our party at least!
We found the old Battalion in front of this Delville Wood, in bits of trenches with 2 or 3 feet of thick slimy mud at the bottom, and straight into this I went.- Those days were indeed "hell" and made me wish for Egypt again with its heat & sand for mud and water were everywhere.
Here in the front- line I had my First narrow escape, a shell burst at my side burying myself and another digger - after pottering round about between the village of 
Flers
 and the trenches, carrying rations or manning trenches for a week or so, we were relieved and marched to a "Nisson Hut" camp at 
Fricourt
,from there after more days of work in the mud we marched to 
Buire
, just beyond

a5760016.html

Albert, and from there by Busses to 
Flescelles
,it was a bitterly cold, snowy, night ride too.
Entry.48:
After 10 days, glorious in spite of drill, we marched to 
Vignacourt 
and entrained for 
Buire
, but as I was billeting N.C.O. for my company I went by motor-lorry, and spent a few hours in 
Amiens
, (a great city) on the way,
Entry.49:
We went up to the mud again - 
Mametz-Wood
, in huts.
Entry.52:
Bn, in 
Gap and switch trench,
- and here we spent Christmas day, shall I ever forget it. I was sharing a "dug-out" with Wally Back and Smithy was orderly Corporal - these were days &nights of hard work - our "home" often required bailing out too. - I got a shell (just a stray) uncommonly close one day - landed right in the trench and knocked "Mick Hallett" and myself over - but not a

scratch.
Entry.53:
Went to "
grass-lane
" where Fritz, plonked big stuff all night- then up to 
"Cheese-road"
 and to such places as 
Frost-trench
, 
Fritz folly, 
and 
Goodwins Post
, where I had various jobs, amongst them patrols and fatigues. Many little incidents - stories in themselves, "Jimmy Maguire's ration party," "The Bombing post blown out" "Old Passmore in the Mud" My day post at Fritz Folly.
Our new year and my birthday
Entry.54:
were not celebrated as times were to hard.

1917
Entry.55:
We were relieved - how thankful we were - in spite of that heart-breaking march in the rain to 
Coolgardie Camp
. This trip was worse than the last, for we had snow and frost as well as rain and mud; was there ever such a winter as this? - trench feet claimed many victims, but I managed to keep going thanks to the sox from the good folk

at home.
Entry.56:
By train to 
Meaulte
, and marched to 
Ribemont
.
Entry.57:
Marched from 
Ribemont
 to 
Contay
 - bitterly cold and hard frost- football in the snow.
Entry.60:
Brigade Support at
 Eaucourt L'Abbaye
, (
Hexam
 
Rd
 - 
Butte-de-Warlancourt
) 
Le Sars
 - 
High Wood
).
Entry.61:
Front line
, snow and freezing cold but thank God! no mud and we had deep dug-outs for a sleep in when off post. Pineapple bombs were Fritz's long suite here - Our boys had a raid on the "
Maize
" here, but the barbed wire beat them.
Entry.62:
To 
Fricourt Farm camp
 via 
Suicide Camp
 and 
Bazentin -le-Petit
 (Birdwood visited us here and told us to keep boxing on).I also visited Doug Black's grave at 
Pozieres
 whilst here and saw our memorial cross erected on the hill there.
Entry.63:
After ten days fatigues we went to 
Albert
 and billeted in the town, only to be sent back to 
Bazentin
, all in a hurry - Fritz was retiring, and we were to follow him - What excitement!
Entry.64:
We occupied the Huns old Front Line System - "Smithy" and I slept on a duckboard, and counting the shells - he was shelling us, as he retreated.
We buried dead men here. - Poor devils had been lying there for months, we worked for days and then had to hurry on leaving many unburied still - A gruesome job, but a duty.
Entry.66:
We went forward at night throught the villages of 
Le Barque
 and 
Ligny Thilloy
 and took up the pursuit.
I had 6 men on a post right on the 
Albert-Bapaume road
, about 1000 yards from 
Bapaume
. - That morning under cover of a dense fog, the "Russian Guards" raided our positions and we

had some good fun, and splendid shooting for our rifles and Lewis Guns. (I captured 2 prisoners) in this little affair, not many Prussians got back to Prussia, but we also lost some good men. - He managed to bomb our Company Headquarters.
Entry.68: Div. took up the pursuit and entered Bapaume a few days later.)
Entry.69:
We then went to 
Contal Maison Montauban
 and to billets (the same old ones) at 
Ribemont
.
Entry.71:
Div. Inf. School, 
Tirancourt
 and had a fine time - 
Amiens
 - 
Le Chausee
 - 
Picquigny
- 
Ailly-sur-Somme
 - 
Villers Bocage
, - 
Haiponville
- 
Bouzincourt
.
Entry.72:
Fancy being able to March in broad daylight up the Albert-Bapaume Road to right into 
Bapaume
 - poor old place! - what a ruin it was and stilll smoldering - then we went
Entry.73:
on to 
Bancourt
 - where our boyswere resting after Bullecourt,(another big stunt I managed to miss.
Entry.75:
Marched to 
Buire
 and our well earned rest - for the Battalian stayed at Buire for 3 months.
Entry.76:
Here I was made Lance-Sergeant and sent to 
England
, with 3 others for 6 months duty with the training battalion (so we were told) but for me it only lasted 3 months. - Had quite a nice journey over via 
Amiens
, 
Boulogne
, 
Folkestone
, 
London
, and 
Salisbury
 to 
Larkhill
 on the plains.
Entry.77:
We started duty at the camp, training recruits, during my stay here we were camped near 
Stone-Henge
 - I explored that part of the County of Wiltshire, 
Winterbourne-Stoke
 
Netheravon
, 
Durrington
, 
Bulford
, 
Amesbury

and various other picturesque rural villages were objects of our various Sunday afternoon walks. I had two days at 
Salisbury
 and two in 
London
, at Salisbury (Old Sarum) I explored its wonderful Cathedral there, and other ancient sights, - and in London I visited 
Regent's Park
 (zoo) and Madame Tussards Waxworks.
Entry.79:
I had 10 days leave and further explored 
London
, 
The Thames
, 
Richmond
, 
Kew
, 
Putney
 and 
Hampden Court
(Wolseley's Palace) - 
The Art Gallery
 and I visited Eric Lowe's grave in 
Nunhead Cemetery
. - Then had a few days at 
Lancaster
 and 
Morcambe Bay
 - then on to Glasgow, and while there saw 
Balloch
, 
Loch Lomond
, 
Dumbarton
, 
Old Kilpatrick
, 
Partick
, 
Paisley
 etc. Had a grand time but didn't think Loch Lomond worthy of all its praises, it is no prettier than 
Awe
, 
Etive
or 
Leven
, but nevertheless it is very big & grand looking.
Entry.80:
I was recalled suddenly to 
France
 - I went via 
Folkestone
 - 
Boulogne
 and 
Havre
, up to 
Caestre
. Here we waited in Reserve for we heard the Battalion were heavily engaged in the "
Entry.82:
We expected it and were ready; we were called up at midnight, and went to 
Ypres
, then to 
Cafe Belge
, and on to 
Dickebusch
 where the boys were - Next night to 
Anzac Ridge in Trenches
. My! what a night and dark, we got lost a few times, 
Jabber Track
 and 
Helles Track
 at last! and we got there - I had No. 9 Platoon. Next day we witnessed some rather exciting Aerial Combats, and that night were relieved, and went to 
Half-Way House
, then to 
Whippenhock (Mud-Farm
) via 
Ypres
. - Here I had my first good look at that poor battered city, and battered it is. They say, the most knocked about cityin the battle Zone anywhere!
Entry.83:
Found us in billetts outside 
L'Abelle
,where we had nightly shows by

Fritz's planes, and our searchlights quite interesting too. Then another trip to 
Ypres
, 
Cafe Belge
 and 
Westhoek Ridge
 via 
The Menin Road
,
Menin-Gate
, 
Birr Cross-Roads
, 
Hell-Fire corner
, 
Hooge Dump
, and 
Jabber-track
. Had a rough trip in too,remember the hammering - Five daysparticular hell on 
Westhoek
 then up the line to 
Zonnebeke
- I had the platoon without any assistance all this time having neither an officer or N.C.O.s, so have cause to remember it. - anyway it ended at last. - but they must give us another few days on that death trap 
Westhoek
 before going back.
Entry.85:
Started a six days march (some mad doctor's remedy for trench feet) ending near 
Boulogne
, our nightly halting places were 
Berthen
, Z
uytpeene
, 
Wardrecques
, 
Remilly-Wirquin
, 
Blequin
, ending at 
Tingry
 outside 
Samer
, near 
Devres
, at Berthen Isneaked a trip to 
Bailleul
 (an old acquaintance). This march was quite pleasant, for

they caried extra packs (a wonder). However we had a pleasant 3 weeks at 
Tingry
 and 
Leave to Boulogne
.
Entry.87:
Army Musketry School at 
Northbecourt
 via 
St Omer
. Had a stay in 
Lumbres
 on the way. - Spent Christmas, New Year and my
Entry.88:
birthday here and they were all properly "kept up" too. It was bitterly cold and snow lay thick, but better than the trenches and appreciated accordingly.

1918
Entry.89:
Found the Battalion again at 
Wytschaete
, there just in time to do a few fatigues, a trip to t
he trenches
, and be made full Sergeant, and was sent back to 
Kemmel
, stayed with the Transport at 
Lindenhoek
 a week visited 
Dranoutre
, 
Messines
.
Entry.90:
Climbed 
Mount Kemmel
 and on the
Entry.91:
humped my pack gladly to 
Bailleul
"en route" for another Musketry School - in England too.I went via 
Calais
, 
Dover

and London to 
Hayling Island
 which is
 off Portsmouth
 and looking across 
the Solent
 to the 
Isle of Wigh
t, it was a charming spot, and I had the unique experience of being billeted in England - quite different to France.The School lasted 3 weeks and I had 3 week-ends in 
London
, then 7 days leave which I spent in 
Glasgow
, returning to 
France
 via 
London
, 
Calais
, and 
Dover
-I rejoined at 
Ridgewood
 and all that month we did heartbreaking fatigues to such places as 
Hill 60
, 
Image Avenue
, 
Shrewsbury Fores
t, 
Klein Zillebeke
 etc. - proceeding by light railway to 
Spoil-Bank
 - I remember one very close shave right on top of 
Hill 60
- at broken-bridge, but that's another story in itself.
Entry.92:
We went to 
Larchwood tunnels
 and had a very "Gassy time".
Entry.93:
Went to 
Tournai Camp
 
Ridgwood

at 
Confusion Corner
, and heard of the German offensive. HereI was transferred to Battalion H.Q. as Musketry Sergeant.
Entry.94:
"Hurry up" for 
the Somme
 - light railway to 
Hoograaf (Poperinghe
) marched by night to 
Godewaersvelde
, and entrained for 
Amiens,
(St Roch Station). Forced march back to 
Raineville
, and another to 
Beaucourt-sur-Huille
, (I was the rear party).
Entry.95:
"British retreating up North" off we go again. Marched back to 
Amiens
, where we spent what was left of the night - bombed from the air (was blown up by one) and shelled heavily.
Entry.96:
Entrained at 
St Roch
 and went on the 
St Pol-Doullens
 Line (which was under shell fire) did ever a troops train move so fast. Stopped at 
Hazebrouck 
- which place was in danger - the line was broken - everyone was in

flight - soldiers and civilians, and we quietly detrained, dumped our packs on the side of the road, and marched to meet Fritz. Such sights we saw that night and next day and we realised that everything, 
Hazebrouck
, 
St Omer
, and the 
Channel Ports
, depending upon our one little division. But we were the "
Entry.97:
Australian Division
" and that's why we were there, and we did the impossible, we stopped him for good and all.
Entry.98:
We entrenched in front of 
Strazelle
, facing 
Merris
 and stopped the advance on this line - 11 days our boys held those outposts without relief. I spent most of that time in cellars in 
Strazelle village
, while it wassteadily pounded to pieces by H.E. Shells - what times! - what feasts - how the champagne flew - what salvage - but what casualties and destruction - shall I ever forget it all.



- a lot of my old friends were killed here.
Entry.100:
I went on an escort job to 
Calais
 via 
St. Omer
, had a rough spin getting out and what pitiable sights behind the line - refugees everywhere, but I returned by a roundabout way a few days later via Burgette and Aire, to Borre Siding, where the boys were having a few days rest but still under shell fire.
Entry.101:
Then another trip to the line to Meteran where amongst other things I salvaged wheat - we went in via 
Fletre
 and came out via 
Caestre
 - remember the burning farmhouses?
Entry.102:
Then we went to 
Sercus
 via 
Wallon Capelle
, where we were bombed every night from the air.
Entry.104:
The Battalion stayed in reserve this time at 
Pradelles
, I stayed at 
Hazebrouck
 with the transport and took charge of the Batallion Guard - then to 
Rouge Croix
.
Entry.105:
Back again to 
Sercus
 via 
Hondeghem
, and more moonlight air raids.
Entry.106:
Up to 
Rouge Croix road
 again - big shells on the windmill.
Entry.107:
I went to the "Nucleus Camp" and then to 
Eblingham
 where we had 2 weeks rest and quietness.
Entry.108:
To 
England
 via 
Boulogne
 & 
Folkestone
 for a Cadet School, what luck! Leave in 
London
 and 
Glasgow
 14 days.
Entry.109:
I went to Cambridge University (Trinity College) and started a 6 months course as an officer-cadet, but the story of my glorious times there is too long for these pages, 
Granchester
 
Newmarket
 - 
St Ives
 -
Gog-Magog Hills
 - 
Via Devina
 etc.
Entry.110:
Had some leave and "some time" in 
London
 and 
Birmingham
 (
West Bromwich
 - The famous Black Country).
Entry.111:
The "Armistice
" was signed and all the fighting stopped - what a day - what rejoicings - still

at 
Cambridge
 - what times with Mun.
Entry.112:
Went to 
Catterick
 (Yorks) 
Richmond
 and 
Darlington
.
Entry.115:
Leave, 
York
, 
Peterborough
, 
Grantham
 and 
London
 - then on to 
Edinburgh
 (a noble city) 
Glasgow
 and 
Kinlochleven
. How different in its garment of snow, but still very beautiful. Had "Jimmy" with me - back to 
Catterick
 via 
Berwick-on-Tweed
 and 
Newcastle-on-Tyne
.
Entry.118:
Went to camp at 
Sutton Veney,

Warminster
 (via 
Westbury
) - then to 
Southhampton
 via 
Salisbury
 and over to 
Havre
 - fancy - France again and no war on.
Entry.119:
Train to 
Charleroi
, Belgium, it took 5 days via 
Etaples
 (
Paris Plage
) 
Valencennes
 
Douai
, 
Mons
 - right through the old battle areas. I found the old Battalion 
Acoz
, and stayed there and



at 
Lausprelle
 about 2 months, during which time I visited, the 
Field of Waterloo
, and had a wonderful 3 days, in 
Brussels
.
Entry.120:
Orders for "Home" at last - what an eventful last journey, on about 6 different French railways, to 
Havre
, via 
Mons
, 
Survilliers
, and 
Nantes (Seine
) - Then across to 
Southhampton
, up to 
Warminster
, to 
Longbridge Deverill
.
Entry.121:
My last 4 days in the "Big Smoke" - 
London
, where I said "Good-Bye" to all my friends.
Entry.124:
I started on a final "tour round" visiting 
Bath
, 
Bristol
, 
Gloucester
, 
Stroud
, 
Cardiff
, 
Waterford
, (Ireland), 
Dublin
, and 
Kingstown
, via 
Kildare
, and 
Kilkenny
 - I crossed the 
Irish Channel
 by 
Fishguard
 and
Rosslare
, returned to 
Warminster
. My last impression of 
Old England
 - "
Glorious Devon
", - for I came aboard this old tub "H.M.T. Sardinia"

and sailed the same day from 
Plymouth Sound
 for dear Old Australia, we have passed 
Gibralter
, through the dreaded "
Bay of Biscay
", through the 
Mediterranean
 in "
Glorious Weather
" coaled (a wonderful sight) at Port Said, through the 
Suez Canal
, past all the old spots 
Ismalia
 and 
Serapeum
 to 
Port Suez
; and now we are sweating in the 
Red Sea
 (had the tailend of a Sirocco at Suez): and we are now passing 
Hell's Gate
, and another few hours will see us past 
Aden
; and then out into the 
Arabian Sea
, we willcall at 
Colombo
, on 15th and then across the 
Indian Ocean
, again past, 
Cocus Island
, to Dear old 
Australia
.

We saw the Southern Cross, last night, and how much it reminds us all of home, sweet home.

We will touch 
Freemantle
 (W.A.) 
Adelaide
 (S.A.) 
Melbourne
 (Vic.) and

Finally 
Sydney
 - early in June - Thus ending all these days, nay, years of war, with its accompanying hardships and trials - yet still mingled through it all are times of real joy and happiness.
